adjectives.description: swish (comparative swisher or more swish, superlative swishest or most swish)

examples: This restaurant looks very swish — it even has linen tablecloths.
The Saints, who started the day third in the table, went marching on thanks to their own swish play and some staggering defending by the visitors.

entries.meaning: A short rustling, hissing or whistling sound, often made by friction.
A hissing, sweeping movement through the air, as of an animal's tail.
A sound of liquid flowing inside a container.
A twig or bundle of twigs, used for administering beatings; a switch
(basketball) A successful basketball shot that does not touch the rim or backboard.

examples: "Fairies, nances, swishes, fags, lezzes — call 'em what you please — should of course be permitted to earn honest livings  […]
He got a little swish downriver.

entries.meaning: (uncountable, Canada, prison slang) An improvised alcoholic drink made by fermenting whatever ingredients are available.

verbs.description: swish (third-person singular simple present swishes, present participle swishing, simple past and past participle swished)

entries.meaning: To make a rustling sound while moving.
(transitive) To flourish with a swishing sound.
examples: to swish a cane back and forth

entries.meaning: (transitive, slang, dated) To flog; to lash.
examples: Doctor Wordsworth and assistants would swish that error out of him in a way that need not here be mentioned.

entries.meaning: (basketball) To make a successful basketball shot that does not touch the rim or backboard.
(gay slang) To mince or otherwise to behave in an effeminate manner.
examples: I shall not swish; I'll merely act limp-wristed.

entries.meaning: (transitive) To cause a liquid to move around in a container, or in one's mouth.
examples: Swish the mouthwash around the mouth and between the teeth for one minute.
